definition: Movement that crosses established boundaries, barriers, or territorial limits

positive_examples: The refugees crossed the border into the neighboring country seeking asylum
She slipped through the fence and onto the private property
The spy infiltrated enemy territory undetected
The prisoner escaped through a hole in the wall
Immigrants moved to America for better opportunities
The protestors broke through the police barricade
negative_examples: The train moved back and forth on the same track
She paced nervously in the waiting room
The pendulum swung from side to side
He jogged around the neighborhood block
The dancer moved gracefully across the stage
The elevator went up and down between floors
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: CircularMotion, LinearMovement, RepeatedMovement, VerticalMovement

opposite_reasoning: While BoundaryRespecting doesn't currently exist in standard ontologies, it provides the strongest semantic opposition for AI safety monitoring. BoundaryMovement's children (Escaping, Trespassing, MilitaryInfiltration) all involve boundary violation - the natural opposite is boundary compliance/respect. This is highly relevant for alignment: detecting when AI systems respect vs. transgress established constraints. The concept is abstract enough to cover physical boundaries (like Trespassing) and abstract ones (like rule violations). For Fisher-LDA, this creates a clear axis: boundary-violating behavior vs. boundary-respecting behavior. If unavailable, Confinement provides a solid fallback with better availability but slightly weaker opposition strength.
